Transaction.title: Transaction
Transaction.description: Represents a financial transaction, either an income (receita) or an expense (despesa).

userId.description: Reference to the User who created the transaction. (Relationship: User 1:N Transaction)

valor.description: The amount of the transaction. Positive for income, negative for expenses.

data.description: Date and time of the transaction.

User.title: User
User.description: Represents a user of the application.

definition.description: Stores financial transactions for a specific user. Path-based ownership ensures that only the user with the matching 'userId' can access these transactions.

params.name: appId
params.description: The unique identifier for the application instance.

params.name: userId
params.description: The unique identifier for the user, corresponding to the Firebase Auth UID.

params.name: transactionId
params.description: The unique identifier for the financial transaction.

firestore.reasoning:
The data structure is designed to store financial transactions for users. To ensure security and scalability, the structure is optimized for path-based ownership, which simplifies security rules and enhances data privacy. Each user has a dedicated collection of transactions, ensuring that only the user can access their own data. This approach leverages Firestore's hierarchical data model effectively.

*   **Authorization Independence:** The chosen structure `/artifacts/{appId}/users/{userId}/transactions/{transactionId}` inherently enforces authorization independence. Access to the `transactions` subcollection is solely determined by the `userId` derived from `request.auth.uid`. There is no need to fetch parent document data to authorize access to transactions.
*   **QAPs Support:** List operations are secured because the path-based ownership ensures that listing transactions under `/artifacts/{appId}/users/{userId}/transactions` will only return transactions belonging to the authenticated user (`userId` matches `request.auth.uid`).
*   **Denormalization:** There is no denormalization required. The transactions are user-owned; therefore authorization is achieved through path-based rules.
